issue.title: ci: cmd/mount test causing build timeouts

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
The cmd/mount test has been hanging on Travis for unknown reasons.

```
?   	github.com/[secure]/rclone/cmd/mkdir	[no test files]

No output has been received in the last 10m0s, this potentially indicates a stalled build or something wrong with the build itself.
Check the details on how to adjust your build configuration on: https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/common-build-problems/#Build-times-out-because-no-output-was-received
The build has been terminated
```

In a successful run it takes about 10s

```
?   	github.com/[secure]/rclone/cmd/mkdir	[no test files]
ok  	github.com/[secure]/rclone/cmd/mount	10.648s
```

body:
It still does not seem to be fully fixed: <https://travis-ci.org/ncw/rclone/jobs/545340848>.
I'll try to figure out what part of the mount test is causing the issue.

EDIT: Nope, I'm sorry, can't figure it out. Let me just restart to get rid of the 20 something zombie processes.

This is certainly an improvement, but not a fix :-(

I'll re-open the issue

Not sure if this is the issue I am running on a production server, but I have thousands (and up to hundreds of thousands after a number of days of usage) of zombie processes from rclone mount

Is the workaround purely to set GOMAXPROCS to something > 2 ?

> Not sure if this is the issue I am running on a production server, but I have thousands (and up to hundreds of thousands after a number of days of usage) of zombie processes from rclone mount

Are you mounting and unmounting a lot - if so then this issue describes the problem. If not then it is probably another issue.
 
> Is the workaround purely to set GOMAXPROCS to something > 2 ?

To fix this issue you actually need more CPUs I think. Setting GOMAXPROCs helps a bit but isn't a total fix.

What OS are you on? Maybe you could try `rclone cmount` which uses `cgofuse` which doesn't have this problem?

I think we are running into the same problem on Debian package building if build host has 1 cpu/core: build locks up during testing:

```
=== RUN   TestMount
2021/01/11 15:02:21 NOTICE: Config file "/home/yaroslav/.config/rclone/rclone.conf" not found - using defaults
2021/01/11 15:02:21 mount "Local file system at /tmp/rclone155259612" "/tmp/rclonefs-mount250935435"
2021/01/11 15:02:21 mount OK
2021/01/11 15:02:21 Starting test run with cache mode off
=== RUN   TestMount/CacheMode=off
=== RUN   TestMount/CacheMode=off/TestTouchAndDelete
```
we do not (AFAIK) set any GOMAXPROC env var.  

(I have no `go` , and especially no `go test` knowledge yet :-( ) What would be the best way to instruct to skip that (and only that) test?  I guess there could be some additional `+build` tag `parallel` and then somehow exclude running those tests with it (unless explicitly known/requested to test parallel functionality)?

FWIW, here is a full build log (courtesy of  @sanvila who made me aware of the issue) https://people.debian.org/~sanvila/build-logs/rclone/rclone_1.45-3_amd64-20210104T021522.145Z which

any advice on how to mitigate (exclude  the test) if not to fix, would be much appreciated by yours truly go-ignorant me.

Sorry about this @yarikoptic it is quite annoying and I haven't worked out the fix...  If you want to work around it you can set the environment variable `CI` to something (doesn't matter what). This will stop the test being run.

This was introduced in 08b86cc94bac448677a45a5c1528e932e62bb6a5 which was released in v1.50.0 so if you are building an earlier version then that fix won't work, though you could apply that change as a patch maybe?

> you can set the environment variable `CI` to something (doesn't matter what). This will stop the test being run.

~~would that stop just that test or all?  we can easily stop running all tests, but I would hate to do that.~~ ( no longer relevant)

oh, and my bad - https://github.com/rclone/rclone/commit/08b86cc94bac448677a45a5c1528e932e62bb6a5 is in 1.53.3 so with that we should be all set. I thought that what I was trying to build/test that recent release, but it might have been building 1.45 as we were building in stable debian... (attn @sanvila) I have ran `sbuild -d sid --arch-all rclone` on  1-cpu VM and build passed.  So the issue is "being dealt with upstream" IMHO .  Thank you @ncw !

Glad that is working :-)

Any flaky tests will be disabled by the environment variable `CI` but present on developers computers to give them an incentive to look into them!

It appears that this is a known problem in https://github.com/bazil/fuse/issues/264 or the go runtime https://github.com/golang/go/issues/21014

The solution is to run the mount in a subprocess when we are doing our end to end mount tests which seems like it should be possible.
